item.itunes:title: Ephesians 2:4-7 The Mercy, Love, Grace, and Kindness of God
item.title: Ephesians 2:4-7 The Mercy, Love, Grace, and Kindness of God
item.itunes:summary: Why does God save anyone? Why does he forgive anyone's sins, and make his people alive in Christ? I. Because of his rich mercy, v4a. II. Because of his great love, v4b. III. Because of his immeasurable grace, vv5-7. IV. Because of his kindness in Christ, v7.
item.description:
Why does God save anyone? Why does he forgive anyone's sins, and make his people alive in Christ?

I. Because of his rich mercy, v4a. II. Because of his great love, v4b. III. Because of his immeasurable grace, vv5-7. IV. Because of his kindness in Christ, v7.
item.content:encoded:
Why does God save anyone? Why does he forgive anyone's sins, and make his people alive in Christ?

I. Because of his rich mercy, v4a. II. Because of his great love, v4b. III. Because of his immeasurable grace, vv5-7. IV. Because of his kindness in Christ, v7.

item.itunes:title: Hebrews 2:14-18 God Became Man to Help Us
item.title: Hebrews 2:14-18 God Became Man to Help Us
item.itunes:summary: Why did Jesus share our flesh and blood, adding humanity to his divinity? To deal with all that stands opposed to our eternal good: I. Jesus disarms the devil, v14. II. Jesus delivers us from death, v15. III. Jesus diverts the wrath of God from us, vv16-17. IV. Jesus delivers help to us in our temptations, v18.
item.description: Why did Jesus share our flesh and blood, adding humanity to his divinity? To deal with all that stands opposed to our eternal good: I. Jesus disarms the devil, v14. II. item.itunes:title: Ephesians 1:13 The Blessing of the Holy Spirit
item.title: Ephesians 1:13 The Blessing of the Holy Spirit
item.itunes:summary: I. The Holy Spirit is God. II. The Holy Spirit is the third person of the eternal Trinity. III. The Holy Spirit is God’s gift to every one of his people. IV. The Holy Spirit is one of the two bonds of our union with Christ. The opening words of the sermon invite you to Hebrews, but the sermon is actually on Ephesians! Sorry about that.
item.description:
I. The Holy Spirit is God. II. The Holy Spirit is the third person of the eternal Trinity. III. The Holy Spirit is God’s gift to every one of his people. IV. The Holy Spirit is one of the two bonds of our union with Christ. 

The opening words of the sermon invite you to Hebrews, but the sermon is actually on Ephesians! Sorry about that.
item.content:encoded:
I. The Holy Spirit is God. II. The Holy Spirit is the third person of the eternal Trinity. III. The Holy Spirit is God’s gift to every one of his people. IV. The Holy Spirit is one of the two bonds of our union with Christ. 

The opening words of the sermon invite you to Hebrews, but the sermon is actually on Ephesians! Sorry about that.

item.itunes:title: Matthew 22:34-40 The Greatest Commandment
item.title: Matthew 22:34-40 The Greatest Commandment

item.itunes:title: Matthew 20:20-28 Greatness in the Kingdom of Heaven
item.title: Matthew 20:20-28 Greatness in the Kingdom of Heaven
item.itunes:summary: Jesus says, "But whoever would be great among you must be your servant, and whoever would be first among you must be your slave, even as the Son of Man came not to be served but to serve, and to give his life as a ransom for many.” What is greatness in the kingdom of God? I. What is isn't. II. How hard it is. III. What it is.
item.description:
Jesus says, "But whoever would be great among you must be your servant, and whoever would be first among you must be your slave, even as the Son of Man came not to be served but to serve, and to give his life as a ransom for many.”

What is greatness in the kingdom of God? I. What is isn't. II. How hard it is. III. What it is.

item.itunes:title: Matthew 19:16-22 The Rich Young Ruler
item.title: Matthew 19:16-22 The Rich Young Ruler
item.itunes:summary: A man came up to him, saying, “Teacher, what good deed must I do to have eternal life?” And he said to him, “Why do you ask me about what is good? There is only one who is good. If you would enter life, keep the commandments.” He said to him, “Which ones?” And Jesus said, “You shall not murder, You shall not commit adultery, You shall not steal, You shall not bear false witness, Honor your father and mother, and, You shall love your neighbor as yourself.” The young man said to him, “All these...
item.description: A man came up to him, saying, “Teacher, what good deed must I do to have eternal life?” And he said to him, “Why do you ask me about what is good? There is only one who is good. If you would enter life, keep the commandments.” He said to him, “Which ones?” And Jesus said, “You shall not murder, You shall not commit adultery, You shall not steal, You shall not bear false witness, Honor your father and mother, and, You shall love your neighbor as yourself.” The young man said to him, “All these I have kept. What do I still lack?” Jesus said to him, “If you would be perfect, go, sell what you possess and give to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven; and come, follow me.” When the young man heard this he went away sorrowful, for he had great possessions.
item.content:encoded: A man came up to him, saying, “Teacher, what good deed must I do to have eternal life?” And he said to him, “Why do you ask me about what is good? There is only one who is good. If you would enter life, keep the commandments.” He said to him, “Which ones?” And Jesus said, “You shall not murder, You shall not commit adultery, You shall not steal, You shall not bear false witness, Honor your father and mother, and, You shall love your neighbor as yourself.” The young man said to him, “All these I have kept. What do I still lack?” Jesus said to him, “If you would be perfect, go, sell what you possess and give to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven; and come, follow me.” When the young man heard this he went away sorrowful, for he had great possessions.

item.itunes:title: Hebrews 8:6-13 (part 2) The Better New Covenant
item.title: Hebrews 8:6-13 (part 2) The Better New Covenant
item.itunes:summary: Hebrews 8:6 But as it is, Christ has obtained a ministry that is as much more excellent than the old as the covenant he mediates is better, since it is enacted on better promises. I. The new covenant is better than the old covenant. II. The old covenant is the covenant with Israel and Moses as Mediator. III. The old covenant wasn't faultless. IV. the old covenant had faults that invited the longing for a second covenant. V. The fault wasn’t so much with the covenant itself, but with the peopl...
item.description: Hebrews 8:6 But as it is, Christ has obtained a ministry that is as much more excellent than the old as the covenant he mediates is better, since it is enacted on better promises. I. The new covenant is better than the old covenant. II. The old covenant is the covenant with Israel and Moses as Mediator. III. The old covenant wasn't faultless. IV. the old covenant had faults that invited the longing for a second covenant. V. The fault wasn’t so much with the covenant itself, but with the people, v8. VI. The old covenant was more exclusive, and the new covenant is far more inclusive. VII. The old covenant is obsolete but the new covenant endures, v13.
item.content:encoded: Hebrews 8:6 But as it is, Christ has obtained a ministry that is as much more excellent than the old as the covenant he mediates is better, since it is enacted on better promises. I. The new covenant is better than the old covenant. II. The old covenant is the covenant with Israel and Moses as Mediator. III. The old covenant wasn't faultless. IV. the old covenant had faults that invited the longing for a second covenant. V. The fault wasn’t so much with the covenant itself, but with the people, v8. VI. The old covenant was more exclusive, and the new covenant is far more inclusive. VII. The old covenant is obsolete but the new covenant endures, v13.
item.itunes:author: Ted Wenger

item.itunes:title: Matthew 19:13-15 Children in God's Kingdom
item.title: Matthew 19:13-15 Children in God's Kingdom
item.itunes:summary: Jesus said, “Let the little children come to me and do not hinder them, for to such belongs the kingdom of heaven.” I. What does Jesus do for them? v15

item.itunes:title: Matthew 19:5-6 Marriage According to Jesus & Genesis
item.title: Matthew 19:5-6 Marriage According to Jesus & Genesis
item.itunes:summary: I. Marriage is a covenant relationship. II. Marriage is a public and social relationship. III. Marriage is for the mutual help of husband and wife, and their companionship. IV. Marriage is a sexual relationship. V. Marriage was designed by God from the beginning to be between one man and one woman, at one time. VI. Marriage of a man and a woman is about the marriage of Christ and his bride, the church. VII. It is God who makes marriages, not man.

Marriage of a man and a woman is about the marriage of Christ and his bride, the church. VII. It is God who makes marriages, not man.

item.title: Matthew 19:1-4 Men, Women & Gender Dysphoria
item.itunes:summary: Jesus is asked a question about divorce, and he begins his answer with this: "Have you not read that he who created them from the beginning made them male and female..." I. Jesus shows God’s love for people by healing them, vv1-2. II. Jesus shows God’s love for people in pointing us to his Word, vv3-4. III. Jesus shows God’s love for people in making us male or female, v4.

item.title: Hebrews 7:20-25 Guarantor & Intercessor
item.itunes:summary: Jesus is the guarantor of a better covenant, who is able to save to the uttermost those who draw near to God through him, since he always lives to make intercession for them. Why is Jesus a better priest than any other? I. Because of God's oath, vv20-21. II. Because he's the guarantor of a better covenant, v22. III. Because he always lives to intercede for us,, vv23-25.

item.title: Matthew 18:21-35 Forgiving
item.itunes:summary: I. Christians must forgive others who sin against us, and keep on forgiving them, vv21-22. II. But how do we do that? What can give us a heart to do that?, vv23-34. III. We aren’t a forgiven person if we don’t forgive others from our heart, v35.

item.itunes:title: Hebrews 7:11-19 The Imperfection, Impermanence & Impotence of the Aaronic Priesthood
item.title: Hebrews 7:11-19 The Imperfection, Impermanence & Impotence of the Aaronic Priesthood
item.itunes:summary: Jesus is a better hope than the Old Testament law and priesthood could give. Why? Because the law gave a priesthood that brought imperfection, impermanence, and was impotent. But Jesus brings perfection, permanence and power. So in and by Jesus we can truly draw near to God.

item.itunes:title: Matthew 18:15-17 If You're Sinned Against
item.title: Matthew 18:15-17 If You're Sinned Against
item.itunes:summary: What should we do if someone in the Christian community sins against us? I. If we’ve been sinned against, we should confront the person personally and privately, v15. II. If they won’t listen to just you, you should take others along, v16. III. If they won’t listen to two or three people, take it to the church, for judicial action, v17. IV. If they refuse to listen even to the church, let them be to you as a Gentile and a tax collector, v17b

item.itunes:title: Matthew 18:10-14 Don't Despise God's People
item.title: Matthew 18:10-14 Don't Despise God's People
item.itunes:summary: Jesus says "See that you do not despise one of these little ones." To despise is to look down on them, or think little of them, and then treat them like they are insignificant or detestable. I. Don't despise them because of their guardian angels, v10. II. Don't despise them because of their Good Shepherd, vv12-13. III. Don't despise them because of the will of God the Father, v14.

item.itunes:title: Luke 1:5-25 The Providence of God
item.title: Luke 1:5-25 The Providence of God
item.itunes:summary: The outworking of the providence of God in Zechariah and Elizabeth and John and us. I. VV5-7 God’s hard providences for the faithful people of God. II. VV8-13 God’s ordinary providences further the extraordinary purposes of God. III. VV13-17 God’s extraordinary providences fulfill the prior promises of God. IV. VV 18-25 None of God’s providences are frustrated by the fickleness of God’s people.

item.itunes:title: Hebrews 3:1-6 Jesus is better than Moses
item.title: Hebrews 3:1-6 Jesus is better than Moses
item.itunes:summary: We glory in the greatness of Jesus. I. Jesus is faithful in God's house, just as Moses was, vv1-2. II. Jesus is the builder of God's house, but Moses is just a member of it, vv3-4. III. Jesus is the Son over God's house, but Moses was just a servant in the house, vv5-6.

item.itunes:title: Matthew 16:21-23 Rebuking Jesus
item.title: Matthew 16:21-23 Rebuking Jesus
item.itunes:summary: Peter rebukes Jesus and Jesus rebukes Peter. I. Disciples of Jesus need to see the necessity of the sufferings, death and resurrection of the Messiah, v21. II. Disciples of Jesus can be wildly wrong about important spiritual matters, for which we need to be corrected, vv22-23. III. Disciples of Jesus must learn to think God’s thoughts after him, letting him mold our thinking, v23.

item.itunes:title: Hebrews 2:5-9 The Humility of the Son
item.title: Hebrews 2:5-9 The Humility of the Son
item.itunes:summary: Why did God become Man? Since our dignity and dominion were ruined by a man, by a man they must be restored. I. What does it mean to be human? It means Dignity and Dominion, vv5-8. II. What has our rebellion against God brought? Disorder and Death, v8b. III. So what did Jesus do? He came to restore us. He tasted death for us that he might give us life, v9.
item.description: Why did God become Man? Since our dignity and dominion were ruined by a man, by a man they must be restored. I. What does it mean to be human? It means Dignity and Dominion, vv5-8. item.itunes:title: Matthew 16:1-4 Demanding Signs from Jesus
item.title: Matthew 16:1-4 Demanding Signs from Jesus
item.itunes:summary: The Pharisees and Sadducees came, and to test him they asked him to show them a sign from heaven. I. As a master teacher, Jesus repeated himself often. Don't be afraid to repeat yourself. II. Do be afraid of being a Pharisee or Sadducee. III. To put Jesus to the test, to demand he prove himself, is evidence of a hard heart that refuses to trust in him. IV. Jesus exposes them for their worldly wisdom but spiritual blindness. V. An evil and adulterous generation seeks for a sign. VI. The most s...
item.description: The Pharisees and Sadducees came, and to test him they asked him to show them a sign from heaven. I. As a master teacher, Jesus repeated himself often. Don't be afraid to repeat yourself. II. Do be afraid of being a Pharisee or Sadducee. III. To put Jesus to the test, to demand he prove himself, is evidence of a hard heart that refuses to trust in him. IV. Jesus exposes them for their worldly wisdom but spiritual blindness. V. An evil and adulterous generation seeks for a sign. VI. The most significant proof of Christianity is the death and resurrection of Jesus.
item.content:encoded: The Pharisees and Sadducees came, and to test him they asked him to show them a sign from heaven. I. As a master teacher, Jesus repeated himself often. Don't be afraid to repeat yourself. II. Do be afraid of being a Pharisee or Sadducee. III. To put Jesus to the test, to demand he prove himself, is evidence of a hard heart that refuses to trust in him. IV. Jesus exposes them for their worldly wisdom but spiritual blindness. V. An evil and adulterous generation seeks for a sign. VI. The most significant proof of Christianity is the death and resurrection of Jesus.

item.itunes:title: Matthew 15:29-31 The Messiah's Healings
item.title: Matthew 15:29-31 The Messiah's Healings
item.itunes:summary: If you’ve experienced the oppression of spiritual forces of darkness, or chronic disease, or permanent disabilities, or lingering illness or painful injury, you’ve experienced the truth that this world is not as it was created to be. Decay and death have entered in. Miseries abound. And what we need is the healing and hope only the Messiah can give. I. The Messiah’s healings overflow to Gentiles, v29. II. The Messiah’s healings confirm his office and calling, v30. III. The Messiah’s he...
item.description:
If you’ve experienced the oppression of spiritual forces of darkness, or chronic disease, or permanent disabilities, or lingering illness or painful injury, you’ve experienced the truth that this world is not as it was created to be. Decay and death have entered in. Miseries abound. And what we need is the healing and hope only the Messiah can give. 

I. The Messiah’s healings overflow to Gentiles, v29. II. The Messiah’s healings confirm his office and calling, v30. III. The Messiah’s healings provoke the worship of God, v31. IV. The Messiah’s healings aren’t finished.
item.content:encoded:
If you’ve experienced the oppression of spiritual forces of darkness, or chronic disease, or permanent disabilities, or lingering illness or painful injury, you’ve experienced the truth that this world is not as it was created to be. Decay and death have entered in. Miseries abound. And what we need is the healing and hope only the Messiah can give. 

I. The Messiah’s healings overflow to Gentiles, v29. II. The Messiah’s healings confirm his office and calling, v30. III. The Messiah’s healings provoke the worship of God, v31. IV. The Messiah’s healings aren’t finished.

item.itunes:title: Matthew 15:21-28 Grace for Gentiles
item.title: Matthew 15:21-28 Grace for Gentiles
item.itunes:summary: I. God’s grace is for the unlikeliest people in the unlikeliest places, vv21-22. II. Affliction sometimes proves to be a blessing to a person’s soul, v22. III. Christ’s people are often less gracious and compassionate than Christ himself, vv23-24. IV. The fruit of God’s grace, in prayer, humility and persevering faith, vv25-28.

item.itunes:title: Matthew 15:10-20 Cleansing Defiled Hearts
item.title: Matthew 15:10-20 Cleansing Defiled Hearts
item.itunes:summary: I. In vv10-11 Jesus says our problem is not what goes into us, but what is already inside of us. II. In vv12-14 Jesus straightforwardly tells his disciples the Pharisees and scribes can’t be trusted. III. vv15-18 What comes out of the mouth proceeds from the heart, and this defiles a person. IV. And so, in vv19-20, the heart of the problem is the problem of the heart.

And so, in vv19-20, the heart of the problem is the problem of the heart.
item.content:encoded: I. In vv10-11 Jesus says our problem is not what goes into us, but what is already inside of us. II. In vv12-14 Jesus straightforwardly tells his disciples the Pharisees and scribes can’t be trusted. III. vv15-18 What comes out of the mouth proceeds from the heart, and this defiles a person. IV. And so, in vv19-20, the heart of the problem is the problem of the heart.
item.itunes:author: Ted Wenger
item.itunes:keywords: Matthew 15, Pharisees, Scribes, Food Laws, Clean, Unclean, Defile, Mouth, Heart, Ceremonial Law, Dietary Law, Moral Law, Blind Guides, Evil Thoughts, Murder, Adultery, Sexual Immorality, Theft, False Witness, Slander

item.itunes:title: Matthew 15:1-9 When Religion Goes Bad

item.itunes:summary: I. In vv1-2 We hear the accusation of the Pharisees against Jesus. There we see the hypercritical legalism of false religion. II. In vv3-6 we hear the counterattack of Jesus against the Pharisees. He exposes their insincere religious commitments and hardness of heart. III. In vv7-9 we hear Jesus sum up the Pharisees as pretenders, with no true heart for God.

item.title: Matthew 14:22-33 The Sovereign of the Seas
item.itunes:summary: Jesus walks on water and enables Peter to walk on water. Who is this Jesus? I. He’s The prayerful man, vv22-23 where Jesus goes up on the mountain to pray. II. He’s The sovereign of the seas, vv24-25 where Jesus walks on water. III. He’s The great I AM, vv26-27 where Jesus calms their fears by revealing himself. IV. He’s The enabling Lord, vv28-29 where Jesus enables Peter to walk on water. V. He’s The swift rescuer, vv30-31 where Jesus lifts Peter just as quickly as he shrieks “save me...

He’s The enabling Lord, vv28-29 where Jesus enables Peter to walk on water. V. He’s The swift rescuer, vv30-31 where Jesus lifts Peter just as quickly as he shrieks “save me.” VI. He’s The adored deity, vv32-33 where the disciples confess & worship Jesus as the Son of God.

item.itunes:title: Genesis 3:20-24 Paradise Lost & Paradise Regained
item.title: Genesis 3:20-24 Paradise Lost & Paradise Regained
item.itunes:summary: Adam’s rebellion brings banishment for him and all his posterity from the enjoyment of the presence of God in the garden of paradise. But Christ is the Last Adam, and his obedience opens the door of access to the enjoyment of the presence of God for all who come to God through him. I. God's promise, v20. II. God's provision, v21. III. God's protection, v22. IV. God's preservation, v24

item.itunes:title: Psalm 118 God's Goodness and Love Amidst Our Distresses
item.title: Psalm 118 God's Goodness and Love Amidst Our Distresses
item.itunes:summary: The last song Jesus sang publicly before his betrayal and crucifixion was Psalm 118 which begins, "Oh give thanks to the LORD, for he is good; for his steadfast love endures forever!" Can you imagine? What about us? How can we sing that God is good, and is being good to us, when life hurts us and people are hateful to us? I. Celebrate the goodness of God and his love, vv1-4 II. See that Jesus suffered like us, as an example, vv5-21. III. See that Jesus suffered for us, as our Sav...
item.description:
The last song Jesus sang publicly before his betrayal and crucifixion was Psalm 118 which begins, "Oh give thanks to the LORD, for he is good; for his steadfast love endures forever!" Can you imagine? What about us? How can we sing that God is good, and is being good to us, when life hurts us and people are hateful to us? 

I. Celebrate the goodness of God and his love, vv1-4
II. See that Jesus suffered like us, as an example, vv5-21. 
III. See that Jesus suffered for us, as our Savior, vv22-29.
item.content:encoded:
The last song Jesus sang publicly before his betrayal and crucifixion was Psalm 118 which begins, "Oh give thanks to the LORD, for he is good; for his steadfast love endures forever!" Can you imagine? What about us? How can we sing that God is good, and is being good to us, when life hurts us and people are hateful to us? 

I. Celebrate the goodness of God and his love, vv1-4
II. See that Jesus suffered like us, as an example, vv5-21. 
III. See that Jesus suffered for us, as our Savior, vv22-29.

Remember men and women are the image/idol of God on the earth, vv16-18.

item.itunes:title: Psalm 109 Judas, Jesus, and Justice
item.title: Psalm 109 Judas, Jesus, and Justice
item.itunes:summary: The Psalmist prayed against one who "did not remember to show kindness, but pursued the poor and needy and the brokenhearted, to put them to death. He loved to curse; let curses come upon him!" What should we make of this? I. The psalmist’s complaint to God, vv1-7. II. The psalmist’s curses, vv8-15. III. The wicked man’s character, vv16-20. IV. The psalmists’ cry to God, vv21-29. V. Congregational praise, vv30-31.

item.itunes:title: Psalm 108 Courage Facing Trouble
item.title: Psalm 108 Courage Facing Trouble
item.itunes:summary: How can we walk with God in such a way that as we fight our battles against the world, the flesh and the devil, we can do so without our heart melting in fear, without giving up? Pay attention to: I. The steadfast love of God, vv1-4. II. The saving glory of God, vv5-6. III. The sovereign promises of God, vv7-9. IV. The certain victory of God, vv10-13.

item.itunes:title: Matthew 13:44-46 God's Treasure
item.title: Matthew 13:44-46 God's Treasure
item.itunes:summary: Jesus says, “The kingdom of heaven is like treasure hidden in a field, which a man found and covered up. Then in his joy he goes and sells all that he has and buys that field. Again, the kingdom of heaven is like a merchant in search of fine pearls, who, on finding one pearl of great value, went and sold all that he had and bought it." I. God Values His People. II. God Determines to Acquire His People. III. God Gives Everything to Purchase His People. IV. God Does it For Joy.
item.description:
Jesus says, “The kingdom of heaven is like treasure hidden in a field, which a man found and covered up. Then in his joy he goes and sells all that he has and buys that field. Again, the kingdom of heaven is like a merchant in search of fine pearls, who, on finding one pearl of great value, went and sold all that he had and bought it."

 I. God Values His People. II. God Determines to Acquire His People. III. God Gives Everything to Purchase His People. IV. God Does it For Joy.

 I. God Values His People. II. God Determines to Acquire His People. III. God Gives Everything to Purchase His People. IV. God Does it For Joy.

item.itunes:title: Matthew 13:1-9, 18-23 The Shallow Hearted
item.title: Matthew 13:1-9, 18-23 The Shallow Hearted
item.itunes:summary: Jesus says, "As for what was sown on rocky ground, this is the one who hears the word and immediately receives it with joy, yet he has no root in himself, but endures for a while, and when tribulation or persecution arises on account of the word, immediately he falls away."

item.itunes:title: Matthew 13:1-17 Why Parables?
item.title: Matthew 13:1-17 Why Parables?
item.itunes:summary: To you it has been given to know the secrets of the kingdom of heaven, but to them it has not been given. For to the one who has, more will be given, and he will have an abundance, but from the one who has not, even what he has will be taken away. I. Parables judge unbelief, vv10-13. II. Parables fulfill prophecy, vv14-15. III. Parables magnify God's grace, vv16-17.

item.itunes:title: Matthew 12:38-45 Give Us A Sign
item.title: Matthew 12:38-45 Give Us A Sign
item.itunes:summary: Jesus says, “An evil and adulterous generation seeks for a sign, but no sign will be given to it except the sign of the prophet Jonah." I. Making Jesus prove himself to you more than he already has, before you’ll trust in him, is evil and adulterous, vv38-39. II. The death, burial and resurrection of Jesus is the sign Jesus has given you, v39-40. III. Pagans repented at the preaching of Jonah and the wisdom of Solomon, so we have no excuse if we reject Jesus, because he’s greater than b...
item.description: Jesus says, “An evil and adulterous generation seeks for a sign, but no sign will be given to it except the sign of the prophet Jonah." I.  Making Jesus prove himself to you more than he already has, before you’ll trust in him, is evil and adulterous, vv38-39. II. The death, burial and resurrection of Jesus is the sign Jesus has given you, v39-40. III. Pagans repented at the preaching of Jonah and the wisdom of Solomon, so we have no excuse if we reject Jesus, because he’s greater than both, vv41-42. IV. An evil generation devoid of God, will grow worse and worse, vv43-45.
item.content:encoded: Jesus says, “An evil and adulterous generation seeks for a sign, but no sign will be given to it except the sign of the prophet Jonah." I.  Making Jesus prove himself to you more than he already has, before you’ll trust in him, is evil and adulterous, vv38-39. II. The death, burial and resurrection of Jesus is the sign Jesus has given you, v39-40. III. Pagans repented at the preaching of Jonah and the wisdom of Solomon, so we have no excuse if we reject Jesus, because he’s greater than both, vv41-42. IV. An evil generation devoid of God, will grow worse and worse, vv43-45.
item.itunes:author: Ted Wenger
item.itunes:keywords: Matthew 12, Signs, Miracles, Unbelief, Evil, Adulterous Generation, Prophet Jonah, Queen of the South, Wisdom of Solomon, Greater than Solomon, Resurrection, Unclean spirits, demons, Holy Spirit

item.itunes:title: Matthew 12:33-37 Our Words and Hearts
item.title: Matthew 12:33-37 Our Words and Hearts
item.itunes:summary: Jesus says, "For out of the abundance of the heart the mouth speaks." What do our words say about the condition of our hearts? I. The character of God is made known to us in and by Jesus, vv33-34. II. Out of the abundance of your heart, your mouth speaks, vv34-35. III. On judgment day, what we are at heart will be proved by what we have said with our mouth, vv36-37.

item.itunes:title: Isaiah 40:1-11 Consolation
item.title: Isaiah 40:1-11 Consolation
item.itunes:summary: I. We need preaching that consoles us with the comfort of God's forgiveness, vv1-2. II. We need preaching that consoles us the coming of God's glory, vv3-5. III. We need preaching that consoles us with the constancy of God's Word, vv6-8. IV. We need preaching that consoles us with the care of God's Shepherd, vv9-11. I'm indebted to my Old Testament professor Dr. Ralph Davis for a significant portion of this outline, explanation, and illustrations.

item.itunes:title: Isaiah 11:1-10 The Root and Sapling of Jesse
item.title: Isaiah 11:1-10 The Root and Sapling of Jesse
item.itunes:summary: The prophet Isaiah's kingdom of the Messiah hope: The wolf shall dwell with the lamb, and the leopard shall lie down with the young goat, and the calf and the lion and the fattened calf together; and a little child shall lead them... They shall not hurt or destroy in all my holy mountain; for the earth shall be full of the knowledge of the LORD as the waters cover the sea. I. His ancestry, vv1,10. II. His adequacy, vv2-5. III. His accomplishment, vv6-9. IV. His attractiveness, v10.

item.title: Matthew 12:15-21 The Messiah is a Servant
item.itunes:summary: A bruised reed he will not break, and a smoldering wick he will not quench. I. See how judicious he is, vv15-16. II. See how necessary he is, v18b. III. See how delightful he is, v18a. IV. See how quiet he is, v19 V. See how gentle he is, v20. VI. See how successful he is, v21.

item.itunes:title: Matthew 12:9-14 Sabbath Mercy
item.title: Matthew 12:9-14 Sabbath Mercy
item.itunes:summary: I. The corporate public worship participation of Jesus is a pattern for us, v9. II. The legalistic hard heartedness of the Pharisees is a warning to us, v10. III. The mercy of Jesus to people is our example, vv11-12. IV. The spiritual blindness and hatred of the Pharisees, vv13-14.

item.itunes:title: Matthew 12:1-8 Sabbath Rest vs. Man Made Rules
item.title: Matthew 12:1-8 Sabbath Rest vs. Man Made Rules
item.itunes:summary: I. Jesus debates the Pharisees because the Sabbath matters as a day of rest for his disciples. II. Jesus rebukes the Pharisees because they laid heavy burdens on people by man-made legalistic and corrupt Sabbath demands. III. Jesus teaches us the true principles that will bless our own observance of the fourth commandment.

item.itunes:title: Matthew 11:28-30 Knowing God is Rest
item.title: Matthew 11:28-30 Knowing God is Rest
item.itunes:summary: Jesus says, "Come to me, all who labor and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest." What an invitation! I. You are invited to come to a Jesus, v28. II. You are invited to receive rest from Jesus, v28b. III. You are invited to be a disciple of Jesus, vv29-30.

item.itunes:title: Matthew 11:16-19 A Fickle and Stubborn Generation
item.title: Matthew 11:16-19 A Fickle and Stubborn Generation
item.itunes:summary: Jesus asks, "But to what shall I compare this generation? It is like children sitting in the marketplaces and calling to their playmates, “‘We played the flute for you, and you did not dance; we sang a dirge, and you did not mourn.’" I. Jesus poses a question. II. Tells a parable. III. Provides an explanation. IV. And concludes with a proverb.

item.itunes:title: Matthew 11:7-15 Believing John the Baptist
item.title: Matthew 11:7-15 Believing John the Baptist
item.itunes:summary: Who is John the Baptist, why did he come, and how does he help us understand Jesus? I. John is the prophet whom Jesus defends, vv7-9. II. John is the forerunner who prepares us for Jesus, vv9-10. III. John is ranked greatest but we’re greater than him, v11. IV. John is the End of the Prophets and Law, vv12-13 . V. John is the Elijah who is to come, vv14-15

item.itunes:title: 1 Peter 4:12-19 Suffering For Being Christian
item.title: 1 Peter 4:12-19 Suffering For Being Christian
item.itunes:summary: I. Don’t let your suffering shake your confidence in the Lord’s love for you, v12a. II. Don’t let your suffering surprise you, v12. III. Instead, rejoice in sharing in Christ’s suffering and glory, v13. IV. And recognize you’re blessed, v14. V. So don’t suffer for doing shameful things, nor be ashamed of suffering for Christ, vv15-16. VI. But keep trusting the Lord amidst his purifying judgment, vv17-19.

item.itunes:summary: A wonderful sermon by Rev. David Wilson, founder and director of Bent-Tree. item.description:
A wonderful sermon by Rev. David Wilson, founder and director of Bent-Tree. 

Bent Tree exists to remind pastors of their callings as followers of Jesus, pastors, husbands, fathers, brothers, children, and friends.  We provide rest, wisdom and fellowship through online communities, national gatherings and training events, pastoral coaching relationships, and counseling.  We want healthy pastors for healthy churches and a healthy society.  Everyone is welcome, our only agenda is the health of your soul and the sharpening of your callings. https://pcamna.org/ministry/bent-tree/
item.content:encoded:
A wonderful sermon by Rev. David Wilson, founder and director of Bent-Tree. 

Bent Tree exists to remind pastors of their callings as followers of Jesus, pastors, husbands, fathers, brothers, children, and friends.  We provide rest, wisdom and fellowship through online communities, national gatherings and training events, pastoral coaching relationships, and counseling.  We want healthy pastors for healthy churches and a healthy society.  Everyone is welcome, our only agenda is the health of your soul and the sharpening of your callings. https://pcamna.org/ministry/bent-tree/

item.itunes:title: 1 Peter 3:7 Christian Husbands
item.title: 1 Peter 3:7 Christian Husbands
item.itunes:summary: The apostle Peter says "Likewise, husbands, live with your wives in an understanding way, showing honor to the woman as the weaker vessel, since they are heirs with you of the grace of life, so that your prayers may not be hindered." Do what? I. Love her at home. II. Pursue knowing her. III. Show her honor. IV. Be sensitive to her vulnerability. V. Honor her in light of God's treatment of her. VI. Honor her in light of God's warning to you.
item.description:
The apostle Peter says  "Likewise, husbands, live with your wives in an understanding way, showing honor to the woman as the weaker vessel, since they are heirs with you of the grace of life, so that your prayers may not be hindered." Do what? 

I. Love her at home. II. Pursue knowing her. III. Show her honor. IV. Be sensitive to her vulnerability. V. Honor her in light of God's treatment of her. VI. Honor her in light of God's warning to you.

item.title: 1 Peter 2:13-17 Submitting to Government
item.itunes:summary: I. Christians are commanded to submit ourselves to governing authorities, v13. II. Why? 1) Because of the Lord Jesus, v13. 2) Because of the purpose of government, v14. 3) Because of our witness to unbelievers, v15. 4) Because our freedom is spiritual not political, v16. III. Summary: putting government in its place, v17.

item.itunes:title: 1 Peter 1:10-12 Suffering First, Then Glory
item.title: 1 Peter 1:10-12 Suffering First, Then Glory
item.itunes:summary: Peter fixes his eyes on Christ's suffering and subsequent glories, and invites us to join him and these others: I. The prophets who prophesied and inquired about Christ, v10. The Holy Spirit who predicted Christ, v11. III. The earliest preachers who announced Christ, v12. IV. The angels who long to look into the things of Christ, v12b

item.itunes:title: 1 Peter 1:6-9 Faith Faces Affliction
item.title: 1 Peter 1:6-9 Faith Faces Affliction
item.itunes:summary: Peter speaks of our afflictions in light of our assurances, so faith can rejoice even as we grieve. I. An assured faith rejoices, v6a. II. And assured faith rejoices and grieves, sometimes simultaneously, v6. III. Faith is proved genuine and is purified by trials, vv6-7. IV. Faith loves the unseen Savior, vv8-9

item.title: Matthew 10:26-33 Facing The Fear Of Others

item.itunes:title: Colossians 4:3-4 Prayer For Preachers
item.title: Colossians 4:3-4 Prayer For Preachers
item.itunes:summary: Every Christian can have an influential ministry for Jesus by praying for preachers. I. Pray for preachers as if preachers are people too. II. Pray for preachers to have open doors for ministry. III. Pray for preachers to have open doors for God's Word. IV. Pray for preachers to declare the mystery of Christ. V. Pray for preachers to have courage and boldness. VI. Pray for preachers to preach clearly.

item.itunes:title: Colossians 3:21 Fathering
item.title: Colossians 3:21 Fathering
item.itunes:summary: “Fathers, do not provoke your children, lest they become discouraged.” I. Don't start your parenting here in v21, but by believing the Gospel and trusting Jesus. II. Don't start your parenting in v20 concerning obedience, but in vv12-17 with love. III. Do parent in light of v20 "obedience pleases the Lord." Does it please parents? IV. The importance of Father's to God. V. Ways we might exasperate our children to the point of losing heart.

item.title: Colossians 3:9-11 Why Not Lie?

item.itunes:title: Colossians 2:20-23 Freedom, Frustration, and Asceticism
item.title: Colossians 2:20-23 Freedom, Frustration, and Asceticism
item.itunes:summary: How do Christians NOT grow and become more like Jesus? By asceticism. I. It's contrary to who you are in Christ, v20. II. It doesn't have power over your soul, vv20-22. III. It's based on man-made, not God-given, religion, v21. IV. It can't keep you from sinning, v23.

item.itunes:title: Colossians 2:1-5 Assurance & Confidence in Christ
item.title: Colossians 2:1-5 Assurance & Confidence in Christ
item.itunes:summary: In a world as unsettling as this. When we realize our lives are not in our own hands. And that we are subject to all the vagaries and miseries of this life. What can settle our hearts? I. Assurance is a ministerial priority, v1. II. Assurance is a matter of the heart, v2a. III. Assurance is aided in a loving community, v2b. IV. Assurance is grounded in knowing Christ, vv2c-3. V. Assurance prevents deception, vv4-5.

item.title: Colossians 1:24-29 Ministry Worthy of Jesus

It proclaims the mystery of Christ, vv26-27. IV. It seeks our maturity in Christ, vv28. V. It struggles by the power of Christ, v29.

item.itunes:title: Colossians 1:21-23 Don't Stop Believing
item.title: Colossians 1:21-23 Don't Stop Believing
item.itunes:summary: Christians don't need anything beyond Jesus, we just need to keep believing in Jesus. So Paul reminds us of: I. What we once were, v21. II. What we now are, v22a. III. What we will be, v22b. IV. So then, how we must continue, v23

item.itunes:title: Colossians 1:18-20 Jesus: Lord of Redemption
item.title: Colossians 1:18-20 Jesus: Lord of Redemption
item.itunes:summary: Our Maker is our Savior and our Savior is our Maker. He who knows us best because he made us, is best able to diagnose what's wrong with us, and best able to prescribe the remedy that restores us to himself and life as he intended. His remedy is Jesus. I. He's more than you think, v18. II. He's head of the church, v18a. III. He's firstborn from the dead, v18b. IV. He reconciles all things, vv19-20.

item.title: Colossians 1:3-8 Why Christians Thank God

item.itunes:title: Matthew 7:24-29 Hearing & Doing
item.title: Matthew 7:24-29 Hearing & Doing
item.itunes:summary: Jesus says, “Everyone then who hears these words of mine and does them will be like a wise man who built his house on the rock." I. We have only two options: to be wise or to be foolish. II. The wise person builds his life on hearing Jesus, and doing what he says, vv24-25. III. By contrast, the foolish person hears Jesus but does not do what he says, v26-27.

By contrast, the foolish person hears Jesus but does not do what he says, v26-27.

item.itunes:title: Ruth 4:13-22 A Baby Boy Born in Bethlehem
item.title: Ruth 4:13-22 A Baby Boy Born in Bethlehem
item.itunes:summary: I. God's gift to Ruth and Boaz, v13. II. God's gift to Naomi, vv14-17. III. God's gift to history, and therefore to us, vv17b-22. Here in this passage we see three things: 1) Faith sees children are a blessing from the Lord, v13. 2) Faith believes the Lord can restore the years the locusts have eaten, vv14-17. 3) Faith can trust that our afflictions serve the larger purpose of God, v17b-22.

item.itunes:title: Ruth 1:1-22 Providence and Bitterness
item.title: Ruth 1:1-22 Providence and Bitterness
item.itunes:summary: Ruth 1 is the story of famine, exile, and bereavement in the life of Naomi, who becomes an Israelite widow living in Moab. And it's the story of God's covenant love and loyalty. I. God tests our faith by hardship, vv1-5. II. God sustains the faith of his people through hardship, vv6-14. III. God grants faith to the unlikely, vv15-18. IV. God supports our faith unseen, vv19-22.
item.description: Ruth 1 is the story of famine, exile, and bereavement in the life of Naomi, who becomes an Israelite widow living in Moab. And it's the story of God's covenant love and loyalty. I. God tests our faith by hardship, vv1-5. II. God sustains the faith of his people through hardship, vv6-14. III. God grants faith to the unlikely, vv15-18. IV. God supports our faith unseen, vv19-22.
item.content:encoded: Ruth 1 is the story of famine, exile, and bereavement in the life of Naomi, who becomes an Israelite widow living in Moab. And it's the story of God's covenant love and loyalty. I. God tests our faith by hardship, vv1-5. II. God sustains the faith of his people through hardship, vv6-14. III. God grants faith to the unlikely, vv15-18. IV. God supports our faith unseen, vv19-22.

item.itunes:title: Matthew 7:21-23 Genuine & False Disciples
item.title: Matthew 7:21-23 Genuine & False Disciples
item.itunes:summary: Jesus says, “Not everyone who says to me, ‘Lord, Lord,’ will enter the kingdom of heaven, but the one who does the will of my Father who is in heaven." I. Genuine disciples obey God, v21. II. False disciples put their confidence in their gifts but not God’s grace, v22. III. False disciples will never enjoy friendship with God, v23.

item.itunes:title: Matthew 7:15-20 Recognizing False Prophets
item.title: Matthew 7:15-20 Recognizing False Prophets
item.itunes:summary: Jesus says, "Beware of false prophets, who come to you in sheep's clothing but inwardly are ravenous wolves." I. We must beware of false teachers, v15. II. How do we recognize false teachers, vv15b-20.

item.itunes:title: Matthew 7:13-14 Enter the Kingdom
item.title: Matthew 7:13-14 Enter the Kingdom
item.itunes:summary: Jesus says, "Enter by the narrow gate." I. A choice of entrances: Will we go through the wide gate, or the small gate? II. A choice of roads: Will we walk on the way that is broad, or the way that is narrow? III. A choice of companions: Will we follow the crowd, or walk with the few? IV. A choice of destinies: Do we want destruction, or eternal life? For we are all headed toward one or the other.

item.title: Matthew 7:6 Logs, Dogs, and Hogs?

item.title: Matthew 6:25-34 Worry: How to fight anxiety

item.itunes:title: Matthew 6:13 Deliver Us From the Evil One
item.title: Matthew 6:13 Deliver Us From the Evil One
item.itunes:summary: Jesus teaches us to pray, "Deliver us from the evil one." What should we learn? I. We have an enemy. II. We need to know who our enemy is. III. We need to be rescued from the evil one. IV. So put your hope in the Lord, through prayer.

item.title: Matthew 6:13 Do Not Lead Us Into Temptation
item.itunes:summary: Jesus teaches us to pray to our heavenly Father, "Lead us not into temptation..." Why do we need that? What does Jesus mean by it? Do we know our own need? What do we do with our failures, even the failure to ask to be kept from failure?

item.itunes:title: Matthew 6:12 Forgive Us
item.title: Matthew 6:12 Forgive Us
item.itunes:summary: Jesus teaches his disciples to pray, "Forgive us our debts, as we also have forgiven our debtors." I. Disciples need forgiveness because of our continuing sins. II. Disciples ask for forgiveness from our Father in heaven. III. A disciple's prayer isn’t just personal, but communal. IV. A disciple’s prayer for forgiveness is always to be accompanied by a spirit of forgiveness toward others.

item.title: Matthew 6:10 Your Kingdom Come
item.itunes:summary: Jesus teaches us to pray, "Your Kingdom Come." What are we praying for? I. We pray that Satan’s kingdom may be destroyed. II. We pray that the kingdom of grace may be advanced. III. We pray that ourselves and others are brought into it, and kept in it. IV. We pray that the kingdom of glory may be hastened.

item.itunes:title: Matthew 5:38-42 Revenge & Generosity
item.title: Matthew 5:38-42 Revenge & Generosity
item.itunes:summary: Is "an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth" just? Does it allow us to take personal revenge? What should we do when others insult, injure, or burden us? I. Disciples of Jesus are not to respond to others with personal vengeance, v38. II. Disciples of Jesus are to respond with love not revenge, v39. III. Disciples of Jesus are to respond with love and kindness even to our enemies, vv39-42.
item.description:
Is "an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth" just? Does it allow us to take personal revenge? What should we do when others insult, injure, or burden us? 

I. Disciples of Jesus are not to respond to others with personal vengeance, v38. II. Disciples of Jesus are to respond with love not revenge, v39. III. Disciples of Jesus are to respond with love and kindness even to our enemies, vv39-42.
item.content:encoded:
Is "an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth" just? Does it allow us to take personal revenge? What should we do when others insult, injure, or burden us? 

I. Disciples of Jesus are not to respond to others with personal vengeance, v38. II. Disciples of Jesus are to respond with love not revenge, v39. III. Disciples of Jesus are to respond with love and kindness even to our enemies, vv39-42.

item.title: Mark 15:37-16:8 Facing Our Fears

item.itunes:title: Psalm 22 The Troubles, Trust and Triumph of The Messiah
item.title: Psalm 22 The Troubles, Trust and Triumph of The Messiah
item.itunes:summary: Jesus said the Old Testament was about him. Here is the Psalm of the Cross, where his crucifixion and resurrection are foretold in striking detail. Its fulfillment in Christ is evidence of the divine inspiration of the Scriptures, and of God's sovereignty in the details of history. Even more, it's a reason to trust him when you face your own troubles.
item.description: Jesus said the Old Testament was about him. Here is the Psalm of the Cross, where his crucifixion and resurrection are foretold in striking detail. item.itunes:title: Luke 23:44-49 The Death of Jesus: Our freedom, access, and confidence
item.title: Luke 23:44-49 The Death of Jesus: Our freedom, access, and confidence
item.itunes:summary:
What do the supernatural events of the darkness and of the tearing of the temple curtain tell us about the death of Jesus? And how do we benefit?
I. vv44-45 The darkness of judgment against God's Son assures our pardon. II. v45 The tearing of the curtain opens access to the Father through the Son. III. v46 The prayer of Jesus can give us confidence in death like the Son.

item.itunes:title: Isaiah 50:4-9 A Servant for the Weary
item.title: Isaiah 50:4-9 A Servant for the Weary
item.itunes:summary:
God's people grow weary and discouraged, sometimes thinking "The Lord has forsaken me; my Lord has forgotten me." (Isaiah 49:14).
God's reply, in part, is His Servant: 1) v4 The servant is a disciple skilled in God's Word. 2) vv5-6 The servant is a sufferer submissive to God's will. 3) vv7-9 The servant is a believer certain of God's help.
Once again, I am indebted to my Old Testament professor, Dr. Ralph Davis, for his insights into this text. May he live long and prosper!

item.itunes:title: Revelation 2:8-11 The suffering of Jesus' people
item.title: Revelation 2:8-11 The suffering of Jesus' people
item.itunes:summary: How does Jesus comfort and counsel his people amidst their suffering? I. Jesus does not tie their sins and suffering together. II. Jesus points us to himself. III. Jesus will never take us where he has not been. IV. Jesus knows and can stop our suffering but sometimes chooses not to. V. Jesus has a heavenly and eternal perspective on our suffering. VI. Jesus knows the end of our sufferings. VII. Jesus promises that Christians will never face the worst suffering.

item.title: I Corinthians 15:12-23 Does Resurrection Matter?
item.itunes:summary: Does it matter whether there is resurrection or not? Yes! I. vv12-13 If we deny resurrection, we deny the Gospel. II. vv14-19 If we deny resurrection, everything else is pointless, truthless, fruitless, and hopeless. III. vv20-23 Christ's resurrection is the promise and guarantee of the believer's resurrection!

item.itunes:title: I Corinthians 6:12-20 Glorify God in Your Body
item.title: I Corinthians 6:12-20 Glorify God in Your Body
item.itunes:summary: Does God want us to enjoy the pleasures of the body, like food and sex? Yes, in the way He designed for them to be enjoyed, for his glory!Four Arguments to help us glorify God in our body: I. vv12-14 We're important to Jesus, and He cares for us. II. vv15-18 We're united to Jesus, and He's one with us. III. vv18-19 We're indwelt by Jesus, and he lives in us. IV. vv19-20 We're purchased by Jesus, and he owns us.

item.itunes:title: I Corinthians 1:10-2:5 Preaching Christ and His Benefits: Faith Rests on God's Power so Our Unity is Established by Him
item.title: I Corinthians 1:10-2:5 Preaching Christ and His Benefits: Faith Rests on God's Power so Our Unity is Established by Him
item.itunes:summary: Paul preaches Christ, Christ Crucified, Our Calling by God, and our Completeness in Christ, so that faith might not rest in the wisdom of man but in the power of God. And therefore our unity as the people of God is established by God, in Christ crucified for weak people who are made complete in Christ and who are led to faith in Christ by the Spirit and not by man.

item.itunes:title: I Corinthians 1:1-3 Gaining the Right to be Heard
item.title: I Corinthians 1:1-3 Gaining the Right to be Heard
item.itunes:summary: When there are difficult things that need to be said, first we need to gain the right to be heard. Paul wisely begins this way in this letter to the troubled church at Corinth.Listen to me, says Paul, because I have the word of Jesus for you.Listen to me, says Paul, because I believe in the work of Jesus for you.

item.itunes:title: Revelation 2:8-11 The Suffering Church
item.title: Revelation 2:8-11 The Suffering Church
item.itunes:summary: A letter to the church at Smyrna. Jesus gives us perspective on our suffering. 1. He doesn't connect their suffering with their sins. 2. He will never take us in suffering where he has not been. 3. He knows and can stop our suffering but sometimes chooses not to. 4. Suffering can reveal our spiritual blessings. 5. He knows the end of our suffering. 6. He promises us that the worst suffering will never touch us.
item.description: A letter to the church at Smyrna. Jesus gives us perspective on our suffering. 1. He doesn't connect their suffering with their sins. 2. item.itunes:title: Mark 1:9-13 Entering the Dance of God
item.title: Mark 1:9-13 Entering the Dance of God
item.itunes:summary: Under the metaphor of the dance, this sermon explores the mystery of Trinitarian love, how we get to participate in that love, and why it often doesn't feel like it. Outline: The Father's love for His Son, the Father's approval of His Son, and the Father's testing of His Son.This was a Bible study taught to Arkansas RUF. The metaphor of Dance was suggested by Tim Keller who picked it up from C.S. Lewis. Also helpful on this subject was Shared Life: The Trinity and the Fellowship of God's Peop...
item.description: Under the metaphor of the dance, this sermon explores the mystery of Trinitarian love, how we get to participate in that love, and why it often doesn't feel like it. Outline: The Father's love for His Son, the Father's approval of His Son, and the Father's testing of His Son.This was a Bible study taught to Arkansas RUF. The metaphor of Dance was suggested by Tim Keller who picked it up from C.S. Lewis. Also helpful on this subject was Shared Life: The Trinity and the Fellowship of God's People by Donald Macleod.
item.content:encoded: Under the metaphor of the dance, this sermon explores the mystery of Trinitarian love, how we get to participate in that love, and why it often doesn't feel like it. Outline: The Father's love for His Son, the Father's approval of His Son, and the Father's testing of His Son.This was a Bible study taught to Arkansas RUF. The metaphor of Dance was suggested by Tim Keller who picked it up from C.S. Lewis. Also helpful on this subject was Shared Life: The Trinity and the Fellowship of God's People by Donald Macleod.
item.itunes:author: Ted Wenger
item.itunes:keywords: Mark, Trinity, Union with Christ, Justification, Testing

item.itunes:title: Luke 18:1-8 The Parable of the Persistent Widow
item.title: Luke 18:1-8 The Parable of the Persistent Widow
item.itunes:summary: Jesus wants his people to persevere in faith and in prayer as we await his return. And so he builds our confidence to appeal to God for justice, protection, and the final end of all evil. Our confidence to pray is in the character of God, our standing with him, his long-suffering, and the promise of Jesus. Jesus closes the parable with a pointed question to us - do we believe?
